A propguard for a Tarot peeper. There are 2 versions included, both a 2D and a 3D version. The 3D version is better for 3D printing, and the 2D version is better for routing.

The default propguard is made for the 1555 props (https://www.amazon.com/Tarot-Efficient-Folding-Propeller-TL100D04/dp/B00SUYR3SU).

You can increase the radius for the carbon fiber folding 1755 props if you want.

The guards are more useful on the bottom, which you can do by flipping the motor mount, make sure to flip the motor direction as well by switching any two esc leads to the motor.

print_settings.Notes:: Turn support on since there is only a small amount of contact with bed.  I also used a brim of about 0.5mm, but no raft.

title: Coffee Grounds Scoop
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple scoop for your morning grind. I include 1, 2, and 4oz pre-rendered STL files with both smooth and faceted faces for the scoop. Or, use the included OpenSCAD file to design your own.

The model is rotated up 60 degree so that only minimal, tiny amounts support will be used if you allow a 60 degree overhang in your slicer (see photo). This also makes the print footprint smaller, so the part will print on even small printers.

Printer:

Monoprice MP Delta Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Your choice - I used 0,1mm

Infill:

High

Notes:

Turn support on since there is only a small amount of contact with bed. I also used a brim of about 0.5mm, but no raft.

Smoothing and Sealing

I recommend smoothing/sealing to keep the grounds from dirtying up the print when used.

I used a Q-tip and acetone to smooth the finish of the ABS print, painting on several coats to seal the layers together. I poured a tiny amount of acetone into the bowl and swished it around the inside to give a very smooth finish. Let dry for 24+ hours before use.

Since it will be in brief contact with food, I do not recommend painting/varnishing. Since the ABS plastic I used was not declared as "food safe" I can only recommend using your own judgement and proceeding at your own risk.

OpenSCAD for the win

Using OpenSCAD made this very easy to design multiple versions and get a little clever on the print orientation.

By rotating the model 60 degrees upwards, my slicer uses no support inside the bowl or for the handle. A little support does get used on the outside of the bowl, and I also used a brim to provide a better attachment to the bed while printing since it balances on the tip of the bowl.

You can make the scoop smooth or faceted: I like the look of the 18-facet outside finish.

If you play with the code. I recommend you use 180 or 360 facets for smooth outside and 18 for a faceted look. You can use other values, but make it a factor of 360 for symmetry.

Getting too few on the number facets will significantly throw off the volume measurements. For example, using 3 facets makes a cool-looking triangular scoop, but the volume is only about 1/2 of what it would be with a hemisphere. For a coffee scoop that's probably OK, but I would not rely on an odd-shaped scoop to measure cake ingredients.

title: Xmas Tree with RGB Led's
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Xmas Tree

I know its bit early for Xmas but is it really though ;)

things required for the whole build. I'll share the list of items and the aliexpress links.

Tree - Has to be printed in vase mode ( Spiral printing ) with no bottom Layer.
Inside 1/2 - they will create the stand inside so will need some superglue work there.

the built is all solder and programming free so everyone can make and enjoy it.

few things required to complete the project.

Copper Tape - (https://goo.gl/rBbn3K)
RGB slow colour changing leds - (https://goo.gl/4o5koe)
9V battery - ( £ shop)
Battery cover or Cable connector - (https://goo.gl/UD5cvM)

if you look closely the tree inside image will give you the rough idea.

will upload the video link when uploaded.

https://youtu.be/2aP6Ma8JYQA

Check out the video here ( https://www.facebook.com/3dFilaprint )

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

We used the "Mini Kossel" to print the tree.
settings we used were as below.

Filament = PLA Xmas green reprapper tech ( Alternative pick from Fillamentum colours)
Vase Mode or single layer spiral mode
NO bottom Layers
Layer resolution depends on you guys this was a quick test print to see if it works and used 0.3mm layer height on 0.8mm nozzle.

the inside parts were printed normally.

Assembling the inner part.

  • Glue the open edges to the sides of the inside 1 part.
  • use the copper tape to stick to the sides of all panel
  • connect the inside panels with copper tape.
  • you will have 4 sides now connect it in a fashion that if one side is positive the opposite will be negative. ( see the image.)
    then connect the battery wire connector with negative and positive panels.

This point we will attach the battery and test the positive and negative of leds. and with copper tape secure them in place.

and put the tree on top of them all done ;)

have fun building the project if need any help feel free to drop a comment.

title: InMoov - Advanced Eye Mechanism
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is an advanced eye upgrade for the InMoov robot. It features eye lids and independent movement of each eye. The design files include a drill mount for sanding and painting eye balls.

Demonstration videos @: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC-TVs2NgcdnF-nCaefCc6zg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2tN2dbpm3rc
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9xMmtNk8nvE

Note: this is a difficult build as clearances are small and some specialized tools may be required for assembly.

You Will Need:
6x SG90 servos with related hardware and horns
https://www.amazon.com/J-Deal%C2%AE-Micro-Helicopter-Airplane-Controls/dp/B00X7CJZWM/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1506426852&sr=8-3&keywords=sg90
2x 2-56 threaded ball joints
https://www.amazon.com/Great-Planes-Threaded-2-56-Ball/dp/B001BHEFUM/ref=sr_1_sc_3?s=toys-and-games&ie=UTF8&qid=1506223441&sr=1-3-spell&keywords=2-56+thraded+ball+links
2x 2-56 threaded 12" long pushrods
https://www.amazon.com/Du-Bro-801-2-56-Threaded-6-Pack/dp/B0006O4HQS/ref=sr_1_1?s=toys-and-games&ie=UTF8&qid=1506224591&sr=1-1&keywords=du-bro+rod
4 pushrod to servo horn couplers
https://www.amazon.com/Du-Bro-Connectors-Re-Usable-Nylon-12-Pack/dp/B0006O8U0M/ref=pd_bxgy_21_img_3?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=T6TWGRKJFR511VMMFAY5
2x cameras
https://www.amazon.com/Small-Camera-micro-security-Surveillance/dp/B00WSJIMJC/ref=sr_1_12?ie=UTF8&qid=1506426350&sr=8-12&keywords=600+tvl+camera
monofilament or braided fishing line in 6 to 8lb test
Forceps - The non toothed type used for stitches (used to aid installation of fishing line and hinge rods)
small phillips head screw driver (mounting servos and servo horns)
riffler files

I will be adding a assembly manual with instructions as soon as time allows. Extra points for building before instructions are released. lol

Preliminary instructions: (You may want to print these for easy reference!)

  • These instructions are preliminary and by no means complete!! *
    Parts require filing for proper fit as they were designed tight to adjust fit by hand.
    hook servos to control board and center them before assembly

1.) Print all .stl files with a maximum layer height of .1mm for best results. (recommend printing eyeballs first so you can sand and paint them while everything else prints) File rough edges with riffler files and chase all .072" holes with a .07" drill bit except for servo screw holes on servo frame.
2.) Sand and paint eyeballs to your taste using the eyeball cordless drill finishing mounts with a metric screw in the mounts for drill chick. I painted my irises at a .5" diameter as this is the diameter of average human irises (some like the large iris of the original InMoov eyes)
3.) Optional Mount cameras (camera specs will be in official instructions when released) into back of eyeballs. Fix in place with a tiny bit of CA glue. Also fix wires off to side as pictured in eye photo being careful not to add height as the cameras barely fit without hitting gimbal.
4.) Using a hacksaw or jewelers saw, cut and chamfer ends of two 8mm, four 6mm and four 5mm pieces from the non threaded end of one of your pushrods. The 8mm are used for eyeball gimbal to servo frame attachment, the 5mm are used to mount the eyeballs to the eyeball gimbal, the 6mm are used to attach the eyelids to servo frame.
5.) Using small bit of pushrod from last step, attach the gimbals to servo frame with 8mm length rods. You will need the forceps to hold rots for insertion into holes without damaging them. Next mount eyeballs to gimbal using 5mm rods taking note of camera orientation for correct image. Next install ball part of linkage on the beam between eyelids on both pairs. then install eyelids to servo frame using the 6mm rods.
6.) install servos, horns, printed servo horns and, linkages as pictured. bending of connecting rods is necessary to make connections.
7.) Use 6-8LB test monofilament fishing line or similar diameter braided line in four 12" sections. this will leave alot of excess but will be easier to work with in this length. Using forceps to help, use Rapala knots (google it) to tie the four sections of string to each of the side holes in eyeballs. Fish the 4 lines up through the holes in the servo frame. Wrap the lines around printed servo horns of upper servos a couple times and affix them using servo horn holes.
8.) Position completed mechanism behind mask and glue in place. (I recommend hot glue so it can be removed later if needed for maintenance or upgrades as I refine the mechanism)

comments.text:
Hi Peloche,
The eye mechanism was designed to use pieces of the pushrod for hinge material for all moving parts as well as linkages. If the diameter of solid copper wire or even brass wire is the same I see no reason why it wouldn't work as the forces involved here are small. The rod diameter is .072".
comments.author: Peloche

comments.text: Very fast reply John thanks and on top of this the rod diameter ! it's perfect ;-)))
comments.author: Dakota76

comments.text:
Hi Peloche,
Your math is correct as far as diameter. The metric equivalent of 13 gauge .072" wire is 1.8288 mm thus making the cross section of 2.5 mm2 solid wire a good choice. You will no doubt need to do a bit of cleaning of the holes for all the joints/hinges as they were designed to be very tight which would make it easy to bend the copper while trying to push it into the holes. The steel of the original design would not bend easy with a lot more force applied.

comments.text:
To my knowledge, Fred Inmoov is unique.
The head I have is a slightly modified Monnerby head.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:992918
Where Fred differs, I have installed 3 Raspberry Pi3 as well as a 16 channel I2C servo Driver Hat.
This leaves very little room behind the eye's.
As it is unique, it is most likely not worth your time changing it for one robot, The current arrangement you have would suit most Inmoov robots out there.
Is there any chance of you uploading the cad files, I may be able to tweek it my self.
The only other mod that might me useful to others is for different camera types, The inmoov site list two camera's and there are a few who use the Raspberry Pi Camera.
I'm also new to the InMoov, but like you it doesn't stop my from experimenting.

This lamp is designed for an LED "puck" light. Battery operated lights are about $4 each; simply do a web search for "LED puck light" to find several sources. This blog page tells where you can get wall powered lights that are brighter and that work very well: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/wall-powered-led-lights/.

This light uses the same basic geometry as https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2545171, but the sections forming the sides are flipped 180 degrees so they are convex instead of concave. For this print I used 2 different filaments: regular yellow for the bottom and then transparent yellow for the top. The transparent lets a lot more light out, but it also results in more fine stringing. This print took 14 hours 3 minutes using a layer height of 0.200 mm. and print speed of 100 mm/sec.

A strengthened version of Antiklesys' feeder improvement. A must for retraction.

Antiklesys' modifications is a great idea, but there were some concerns in the comments about its strength. There was very little could be done within the existing 4mm wide gap the part sits in, so to make it stronger you also have to change the side supports, part 10A and 10C.
This is a fully printable upgrade of all 3 parts of the assembly, whilst keeping faithful to the Ultimaker original, using the outer shape taken from the lasercut drawings published.
You will need a 6mm ID, 10mm OD, 3mm wide bearing, this cost me Â£1.99 on eBay. This thing really works. It reduced the friction considerably, meaning less pressure needed, less teethmarking of the filament, less jamming of the deformed filament in the bowden, less grinding the filament (none in fact since I fitted it) and much better, quieter retraction performance. Modelled in Siemens NX8, printed 0.1 slice, 100% fill using Cura. No support needed.

comments.text: Prnted well enough for me. The outer wall of the roller is only 0.5 mm thich, so it is very easy to crush the bearing by overtightening the screw. It is a delicate balance. Also, the plastic center for the bearing can break.

title: Dr. Mad Thrust 50mm Alloy EDF Thrust Tube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Just a simple thrust tube for a Dr. Mad Thrust 50mm EDF. It has an 8% Diameter Reduction at the exit which should give you a good mix of speed and and torque. The tube is 50mm long and there is an extra 20mm that couples it to the EDF, while the optimal length is about 4x the diameter of the EDF which would be 200mm that simply wouldn't fit on my HK FlyCat. There are three different versions of the tube, V1 which is only the tube with no wire holes or mounting bracket, V2 that has the mounting bracket for the FlyCat, and V2 Wire Hole that has a hole for my motor leads to go through. I included the STL's for all the designs as well as the 123D designs so you can make your own. Below is a transcript of a .txt file I have with all the dimensions of the EDF and tube. Also I designed this with a lot of help from THIS thread, its super useful and I recommend you check it out.

EDIT: Added a model, V3 Side Plates, that has plates that come out of the edges for mounting on flat 5mm thick foam.

.

description.text:
A tatted bookmark (or lace edging) in 4 sizes. The smallest size needs to be printed on high quality, but the others are okay printed at .2 layer height, or if you adjust slicer settings, one pass at .3 layer height works great!

The largest one is 152.5 long, next is 133.7mm, 115mm, and the smallest 104.7mm.

You can use a hair drier to quickly deform this lace, making it suitable for other decorative uses... edging a shelf is a favorite of mine, but you can also curve it around your wrist and tape it into your sleeve for a quick Victorian looking touch.

https://youtu.be/r3Y0f_ElaGQ

If they deform slightly taking them off the print bed, put it back on the warm print bed (preheat if necessary) and use a clean dry rag to press it flat again.

See video above, but you can also deform it with a hair drier.
Softmounts for the T-Motor F80. The center hole has a diameter of 9mm, and the piece is 1.5mm thick. I printed a layer height of 0.2mm, which resulted in a layer height of 1.4mm.

print_settings.Notes:: Regular settings for whatever material you use.  I printed mine solid but they probably don't have to be.  A couple outer shells would probably be plenty although they're pretty thin to begin with.  No supports needed.

description.text:
I made these corner reinforcers to be used with 1/2" thick foil backed foam insulation to make a heated enclosure for my Prusa i3 MK2. You can get 4x8 sheets of the foam at most hardware stores. It's a little flimsy but reinforcing the corners makes a big difference. The corners are designed to be attached by pushing a zip tie through the outer piece, through the foam, through the inner corner piece, and back out through the second set of holes, and zipped tight. I used PLA which might get a little soft in the upper corners, but doesn't have a huge amount of force on it so I haven't seen any distortion.

The insulating foam does a good job retaining the heat produced by the printer and I've printed up to 65 deg C with this setup although I start to worry about the electronics a bit at these temps. Oh also, if you preheat the chamber very much it'll mess with the PINDA (if you're using a Prusa, the bed sensor otherwise), you'll want to be ready to adjust the live Z height adjustment to get it back down to the bed.

I reinforced the edges with foil tape and taped a lexan window into the front. I planned on making a zoomy set of doors to go on it with the lexan, but it's so easy to just lift off of the printer that I never bothered.

One last warning: Any PLA parts inside the chamber will get soft if the temp gets very high. I dropped a roll of filament on the bed after my spool holder got soft and gave up...

description.text:
How to show the structure of boron to pupils? One option is to use 3D printed model :-)

The models are small (in CPK variant boron diameter - 12 mm, the size is "compatible" with this molecular set: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2251404). This allows a relatively fast printing many sets of models. That is why each student can work with its own set of models. You can print also a demonstration model (we recommend using Licorice variant in 4x magnification).

In the files there is also model in molecular PDB format (for direct viewing on tablets, smart phones, computers - in molecular viewers like iMolview).

More educational 3D models can be found also on our website http://www.e-mole.cz/3d-model.

title: Makergear M2 Blower Bracket and Duct

description.text:
This is a mod to replace the stock 50mm filament cooling fan on the Makergear M2 with a 50mmx15mm blower. This provides for improved airflow and a quieter print. Optionally you can add a brace to support the ductwork (see optional parts below). I found that his brace was not required as the duct has a snug fit against the blower. Locking nuts were selected to reduce the likelihood that vibrations would loosen the nuts.

If you have made this thing and find it is useful and or has improved your prints, please consider leaving a tip. Thanks!

Also please consider using my Amazon (<-click here!) link when you buy things from Amazon.co.uk. It costs me a lot in filament to design and perfect these things. All support is very much appreciated!

Here is a design I have been working on for a 3:1 geared bowden extruder capable of pushing flexible filament such as TPU.

I printed everything with 25% tetrahedral infill in cura. 4 top/bottom/wall shells. 0.2mm layer height. Some of the fittings are a bit tight and some parts may need some cleaning after printing. Use supports everywhere 10% lines in cura as they are quite easy to remove and help with some parts.

1: Attach the gearbox part to the bowden motor mount (I use: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2369063) attached to your frame using either 4xM3x10MM bolts or other suitable bolts.
2: Fit bearings into main body and top cover, they should push all the way in with a little persuasion.
3: Fit M5 bolt into spur gear and push all the way in. Slide one of the washers on after the spur gear.
4: Push M5 bolt with spur gear attached into bearing in main body from rear.
5: Fit Mk7 extruder gear to M5 bolt and line up with filament holes in main body, it can help to mark where this lines up with the holes and file a flat spot for the grub screw but this is not essential.
6: Assemble arm, put M3 nut into hole in handle and thread 20-25mm M3 bolt in to it from the other side. Put other M3 nut into hex hole on adjuster cog and bolt onto the 20-25mm bolt. Push larger bearing onto the stub at the other end of the arm and then push the stub on arm retainer into the top of the bearing.
7: Attach arm bushing to main body with M3x10mm Bolt from rear. You may need to clean this part up a bit so it fits nicely into the hole on the arm. Slide assembled arm onto the bushing once attached and insert spring between the adjuster and hole on the main body.
8: Fit top cover to main body using 4xM3x10mm bolts. Put M5 washer on M5 bolt on top of bearing in top cover then bolt M5 nylock nut onto M5 bolt. Do not overtighten. The bolt should be able to turn freely with no pressure on the arm.
9: Fit assembled extruder to gearbox using 4xM3x10mm bolts, paying attention to the orientation of the push on gear for the stepper motor. It will only run one way. Attach the pneumatic couplings to main body. You may need to use a spanner as they are a tight fit at first.
10: Calibrate extruder steps per mm. Mine is 316.66 for PLA and 327.59 for TPU.

Leave any comments and suggestions in comments section please :)

Required parts:

Perfectly working one-piece bong with the ability of adding ice for smooth inhalations. Needs only a glass bowl pipe because you can't burn the "material" in pla or abs.

It is my first printable design and I am very proud of it! It has a deep bubbling sound which I love and you can put ice in the top part for a very smooth inhalation. You can paint it with paint for plastics. I recommend a tripping synthesis of two or more colors blending. I painted mine blue-silver with bronze linings and it looks awesome. The material I used was PLA which is biodegradable and poses no health risk and also has no smell.   
The bong is functional (believe me it is), but I had some problems with the printing, most of which I think can be solved by creating better g codes.  
Here are the problems I had:  
1) The bottom of the bong, even if I designed it solid, it is printed thin walled, which gave me some minor leaking problems.  
2) Some even more minor air leaks where the vertical cylinders in the middle join the upper and the lower parts.  
3) For some reason - even if these weren't in the original design - the g code produces some filling layers to be printed in about the 1/3 of the lower spherical bowl.  
4) No choking hole could be designed - the Catia was on its period or something.  
5) Took 12 hours to print because I printed it in the maximum possible quality I could achieve.  
The solutions I found to resolve the above issues were:  
1,2) I used my soldering iron (!) as a brush and heated the bottom and the other places where i had leaks in order to melt just as much as to cover the small holes and stop the leaks.  
3) I was waiting above the machine to print the filling layers (I could see them in the g code preview before the print and with a couple of tweezers i gathered the layers and pulled them out of the object. Careful not to detach the bong, burn yourself or get in the way of the nozzle. You can stop the printing every once in a while to do this more safely.  
4) Again with my soldering iron, i drilled a chocking hole just above the lower spherical part.  
5) I had to smoke normal joints in the meanwhile - it sucks right?  
These were my problems and my solutions. I hope you don't have them, but even if you do the final result will leave you with a smile. For some hours at least.. ;)  
The bong is designed for a 14.5mm glass pipe with a total length of 95mm (with the bowl). You can get one in your local smoking shop or through the internet.  
Important: Don't scale the bong or you could have problems fitting the pipe correctly. If the design don't fit the printer, I would recommend making it a bit shorter by reducing the upper body's height.  
If you have any problems, recommendations or questions about the design don't hesitate to contact me :)  
Have fun and enjoy!

title: Anet A8 brass brush and heater bed wire holder

description.text:
Here's the brass brush and heatbed wire holder for the Anet A8. It will require you to remove your heatbed, as it is mounted on the front left, on top of the aluminum H frame using the bearing block bolts. When tightening those bolts, don't forget to move the Y axis back and forth so you don't bind up the bearings again.

The wire holder has a two spots for zip ties. Use one or two at your discretion.

There's two holes to hold the brass brush with wood screws (#4 I think). Don't make them too long or you risk pushing the brass wires out of the wood!

Happy making (with clean nozzles)

description.text:
Reading this it will get clear that a protecting grille for tilting windows is a must have for cat owners.
This is my first try to make this protections by myself. It is designed for standard windows with a gap of 16cm on the upper corner. Because I have plastic windows I can't use screws. But with thin transparent double sided adhesive tape by 3M the grilles stick strong enough on the window. The foot of the grille will be pressed to the windows frame by the seal of the closed window if it is mounted in the direction shown of the photo. So it is stable enough for curious cats.

Edit 2017/09/23: Added models with screw holes for those who want to fix the parts with screws on the windows frame

  • a selfie stick
  • a camera screw
  • a Gopro alike thumbscrew (or print your own* and use a M5 screw)
  • a M5 (or Gopro) nut

For convenience and because I use it personally I added the excellent Gopro short knob model model by Julien9462 (thing:252554), Thanks dude !

This is a pulley I designed for the Tuco Flyer project, a robot made of several winches that operate on nylon paracord. I couldn't find a suitable pulley designed for light-duty loads to run smoothly on this diameter of rope, so I designed one. The pulley itself runs on two 606 skate bearings over an M6x40 bolt, and the housing is held together by two M3x35 bolts and nuts.

The pulley housing is designed to accept two loops of paracord that each pass through both halves of the housing, additionally holding the housing together and acting as a failsafe so that even if the 3D print fails, the paracord looped through the pulley will be retained by the paracord holding the pulley mount together.

The pulley is printed without support, but the overhang is quite severe and I had to run my printer a bit slower than usual to give good results.

title: DaVinci 1.0 Pro AiO - PLA Fanduct Cooling AddOn

description.text:
Finally is designed a very useful AddOn for the DaVinci 1.0 Pro AiO - PLA Fanduct (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2017981). Works with an E3D v6 hotend.

Take care of the hotend temperature, i added about 10°C. I switch the fan on after about the first 1-3 layers and the results were pretty good so far.

I printed it with supports (not inside the duct) and the fan-slots at the bottom.

Edit - 2017-09-23
There is a small problem with the build plate, but only at the beginning of a print. During the print its fins. So be careful. I am going to change this in the next 2 days!!

Edit - 2017-09-24 - Version 1.3
Testing while printing -> OK!
Testing to set/calibrate z-axis -> OK! (Only a little touching ;))
Testing to switch to engraving module -> In Progress!

Cheers CSD

DISCLAIMER: This is not entirely historically accurate! This was just meant to be a fun representation of a medieval castle to be used as a model, game piece, or just a fun project to show off!

A history project assigned was to create a basic blueprint layout of a manor that a medieval lord or knight would live in with his farmers. My friend and I decided to go overkill and create several little buildings, including this awesome castle! My friend is a historical expert, although our designing capabilities were both limited in experience and time. Well, here it is, enjoy!

I have not added any images because I forgot to take pictures before turning the project in, which did look quite nice with paint and other structures like houses, a chapel, and a barn, blacksmith, and mill.

description.text:
My favorite knife brand! Microtech!

MICROTECH KNIVES was established in 1994 in Vero Beach, Florida relocating to Bradford, Pennsylvania in 2005. We have always operated with a simple mission:

TO MAKE THE BEST POSSIBLE KNIVES.
This mission is still true today.

Our goal is to attain and maintain extremely high quality knives throughout the evolution of growth and change. Founder, Anthony Marfione’s objective is to ensure that every day, each customer will receive the highest quality knife that money can buy. We deliver personalized service with exceptional attention to detail. Even though we produce thousands of specialized knives, the quest for quality remains our primary focus.

The MICROTECH Reputation Has Continued To Stress Quality Which Means:
Extremely close tolerance – Our Designers and Technicians measure to the thousandths to ensure precision action.
Only USA manufactured parts, material and labor.
We research and test only the highest grade of Tool Steel, Aircraft Alloy and component pieces – all developed by USA Manufactures.
Approximately 95% of all parts are fabricated by us not for us.
Designed and engineered by experts –aiming to meet and exceed customer needs, targeting ease in application and effectiveness.
Lifetime limited warranty of all MICROTECH WORLDWIDE products.
NO COMPROMISES ON QUALITY!
During our history, we have produced revolutionary Tactical Knives, and in keeping with our tradition, we continue to introduce new innovative products, striving for excellence.
Even through our most recent expansion to Bradford, PA, Founder Anthony Marfione remains committed to keeping"

This is a landing gear strap I made for my FT 3D RC airplane. The stock plane uses a rubber band to hold the landing gear on, but the rubber bands were always breaking, so I decided to design these. You can easily find these in a hobby shop, but they are rather expensive for what they are. The store-bought ones are usually nylon, and probably more rugged than the PLA ones I made, but these are cheap and served as my first design in Fusion 360.

title: Isle of Trains card game inlay

description.text:
Isle of Trains is a card game that comes in a box that's a little too big for the cards. It's not really a problem but I wanted a simple 'problem' to solve and this fitted the bill perfectly.

There are no finger slots as I thought it looked better without them, plus it's easy enough to flip the box over. Also, I messed up in Tinkercad with the hole: I didn't lower it through the plane, so there's an internal lip at the bottom of the card slot. I was going to fix it but I kinda like it, especially in grey filament that matches the cardboard. It also stop the cards from sliding underneath the insert.

Possible improvements: add a thin base so that it can be printed with 0% infill and no top. Then it could be flipped over to hide the hollow section and would use a lot less material.

title: Sentry Gun [28mm]
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I couldn't get the Sentry Gun by bulldog2708 to print reliably or nearly as well as their demo pic, so I reworked it to be more robust and come out more cleanly.

No rafts or supports are required. Print 4 of the legs.

There are four versions of the heavy machine guns:

  • Regular, which has some minor overhangs in the barrel that interact with the thin walls to sometimes deform a little in printing.
  • Fully supported, which doesn't have a fully hollow barrel and extends the bottom bar all the way out to the tip of the nozzle, so the barrel in theory doesn't look quite as cool, but in practice won't deform as much so might look better after all (and the insides can be fully drilled out if desired).
  • Split, which print as two halves on end to be glued together, so supports aren't needed but the overhangs are maintained.
  • Split v2, which moves the split point up just behind the barrel. This makes the stock of the gun straighter and cleaner, but distortions from a heated plate may be trickier to clean up in that area. Try both out to see which you like more.

Maybe you can't see it see it coming because your view is blocked by cheap facades of skylines and cityscapes. But you had better make ready my friends, because this thunder is preparing to rain down fear and terror on your gilded houses of complacency! Mark my words big-shot late night gabfest mavens! You're about to tangle with a one dimensional caricature and his long forgotten arch nemesis pals, a bug and a... What are you anyway, Moltar?"

Moltar: "I am a poorly drawn lava kind of a molten man."

Space Ghost: "And a poorly drawn lava kind of molten man! There is a new player in this late night talk show war, and his name is..."

Printed in white, black, yellow, and tan filament.

Supports are built into the files.

Small parts included. The second face is in case you have trouble printing his winning smile. You can paint the eyes on if your printer has trouble printing them.

The base is not needed (he stands fine on his own), but if you choose to print it, you'll need to change filament colors during printing. Check your slicer to determine the correct timing.

High Peak map of the region in the Adirondacks. Map to envelop the 46 high peaks. Created using Terrain2STL (http://jthatch.com/Terrain2STL/). You may need to scale the x/y to fit your print bed, but z is adequate. The elevation scale is 2:1 already, so some scaling error will occur, but I found this to be the best for printing.

I printed a thicker infill (70%) to help avoid some issues with gaps showing in the terrain. I plan on marking my routes I've taken on the peaks. I showed the approximate range in the photo. The plate is bordered in the south by Route 87, to the east by I-87, to the north just north of Esther, and the West by the Seward Range. All 46 peaks should be in there.

title: Anet A8 filament guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A small piece that inserts into the extrusion mechanism to shorten the distance between the filament propeller and the tube, so as to avoid the filament escaping the expected path. Aimed at improving Flex printing. Designed for the Anet A8, but should work with any Prusa i3 or any printer that uses the same extruder assembly.

IMPORTANT NOTE: this is a work in progress, currently it doesn't work because I can't get the right dimensions... DON'T PRINT THIS as once assembled, the slight misadjustment prevents filament from effectively finding its way into the tube. Any contributions are welcome, attached is the Blender file that allows to adjust the dimensions and then get the piece together by boolean substractions.

EDIT: the idea is nice, but after doing some web search I found you might wish to use an MK10 extruder extension kit, which does the same and should cost less than 20$. So maybe there's not much point in continuing this research, anyway plastic would tend to melt in these conditions, potentially causing a disaster.

title: WOLFTEK QC15 headphone shells (for Bose QuietComfort 15)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE 10.11.2017:

I improved the shells so that they should fit a bit better now. The knob hole is situated more acurate and the inner screw holes have been reinforced.

ORIGINAL SUMMARY:

I never liked the standart QC15 Shells. They make the headphones look so old fashioned. I searched for some custom shells on many 3D platforms but couldn't find any so I made these myself. They fit ... but they don't fit perfectly. This is my first 3D design. Never used CAD before so excuse any big mistakes. I went with a 3D honeycomb style.

I printed on a Tevo Tarantula with 0.4mm nozzle. You might be able to get better results with a finer nozzle and/or a better printer.

I am working on releasing different designs of the shells so you are not stuck only with the honeycomb design.

title: Frostmourne - Warcraft
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The sword of the Lich King, Arthas, from Warcraft. Even for those who don't play (myself included, ironically), this is a testament to your 3D Printing skill and endurance.

https://www.myminifactory.com/object/frostmourne-from-warcraft-4156 is the original, but it needed some fixing up for printing. Details in the "How I Designed This" section.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

5-10%

Notes:

I reccomend a high layer height because these peices are qite big. I pre-included supports, but I've included the original files for those who find them unsatisfactory. I don't reccomend changing the orientation of the files, especially the blade pieces for infill purposes.

Use a hammer to join the parts together, but have patience, lest you break the pieces. Make sure you have two of the "Handle x2" pieces. There is also a file in the original called "frostmourn-8" that takes the place of one of them, but it makes the handhold much smaller.

First, I scaled all parts down by 75% so they would all fit on my buildplate, and rotated to them to the optimal print position. Next came the supports, I auto generated most of them, but those often needed tailoring afterwards. I also cut the "Hilt" in half for a nice clean surface for the bottom.

author: Clathymore

description.text:
I've bought a used Dobby drone without a battery lately and because of the not so cheap original batteries I decided to design a battery case for LiPo cells. In this case I've used two 1200mAh Turnigy nano tech cells, which have a round shape.

Update: unfortunately these cells have a massive voltage drop under heavy load. This causes the Dobby to land after 6:30 minutes although there's still a third of the capacity left in the cells. The cells are getting quite hot. The 15C rating doesn't really apply to these cells.
I will keep looking for suitable cells and post updates here.

Because of the thin walls which are hardly printable upright, I designed a kit which has to be assembled after printing. I've used super glue.
The hardest part has been the connector.The last picture shows a making of. I've used the contacts from a 2.54mm female header connector, pulled them out, straightened them, stacked and soldered them, filed the inner ones down to 1.75mm (from 2mm), soldered the cables, put them into the case and glued the cap on.

comments.text:
Wiring is quite simple. Have a look at the right end of the last picture. There you see the completed connector before closing it's housing. The yellow wires are positive, the black ones negative.
The two lipo cells are connected in series, so the wires connect to the positive of the one and the negative of the other cell.
The balance plug is connected as follows: red=positive, black=negative (like the case connector), yellow=in between cells

comments.text: I tried printing this as well on a Makerbot Replicator 5th Gen and had the exact same problem, the "threading" on the top and bottom (or basically the beginning and end of the printing process) it's not joining the filament as densely as needed.  I've tried to print this three times, once with slightly modified settings (faster and hotter, draft print settings), and then again with default settings, and a third time with "Best quality" settings.  The area where the "neck" and body of the water bottle meet, is also too weak, and on all three versions can simply be pressed in. None of my water bottles could hold water :( ....but I still like this project and want to see it work!
comments.author: davidleach

comments.text: We tried printing this.  As drawn, the outside of the threaded rim of the bottle measures 75mm, but the inside of the cap measures 70mm, so the cap doesn't fit.  There is also a problem with where the threaded section meets the body of the bottle in that the two seem to connect at a line, and there is not material actually joining the two (the top rim peeled off the bottle after printing).

title: Simple Filament Dust Remover (and oiler) (1,75 mm)

description.text:
Simple filament dust remover and oiler.

Instructions:
Cut out a kitchen sponge, fitting in the top part (diameter 10 to 15 mm, heigth 5 to 10 mm).
Make a slit in half to center direction and put in between both parts.
Put it around the filament and turn, until it fastens.
Optional put some oil into the open holes.

This assembly will keep your filament clean during the printing process. Can be assembled without unfeeding the filament.

description.text:
A family member of mine has a ResMed ASV machine with an oxygen generator, and their hose adapter started developing cracks, leaking and disconnecting randomly in the middle of the night.

I made a quick copy of the original piece in Tinkercad with the help of a $9 Harbor Junk caliper, so the fitment on the mask end is a little tighter than it needs to be.

I have uploaded STL's with and without custom supports, I found them to be better than Cura's supports and break away from the part more easily.

Let me know if I should make any revisions, I'm always open to feedback.

title: Articulated lamp with modified arm G-Clamp holder and G9 socket

description.text:
Remixed/based on multiple things there.
Remixed design of arm(s) so there is only one type of arm and they fit. So print any quantity of the arm and screw it together. I have had printed 6 of them and they are pretty sturdy... So you should prolong the complete lamp arm as you want.
There are files with arm with knob or only the arm.

Next thing is G-Clamp - print it as is, and you should clamp your lamp wherever you want. The clamp design is very good (links to originals below).

Last thing is G9 socket - i have many G9 led bulbs 3watts, so i just remixed the original G9 socket to match the articulated lamp far end. But i recommending use of LED bulbs because of heat.

description.text:
Fan duct for E3D Titan Aero.

Sloppy Remix (used tinkercad) E3D 30mm layer fan from E3D.

-Changed direction of air flow.
-Widened screw holes to allow adjusting up and down.
-Added 30mm blower fan adapter.
-Version 1.3 - Added Semi-Circular fan duct

Frustrated with overhangs and fan options, I decided to remix a few parts together and had great success.This has produced the best prints so far.

The fan duct I'm using in this remix is from this post on E3D forums: https://forum.e3d-online.com/index.php?threads/titan-aero-fan-options.2670/

Change Log:
Version 1.3 - Removed Spirya and added Semi-Circular fan duct. Widened screw holes some more to move in all directions. Changed direction of model. Use support.

Version 1.2 - Meshed Spriya Fan Duct for better airflow. Improved quality of prints.

Version 1.1 - Cleaned up a little bit more.

title: Modular Hobby Paint Rack - Small Straight

description.text:
Third of the modular paint racks to store and organize hobby paints. This one is a smaller straight section. It is half the size of the large straight section. I designed this to hold Vallejo or Reaper dropper paint bottles. I will be adding more shelf layouts to hold paints such as Miniataire, GW and others!

Capacity:

  • 18 dropper bottles (Vallejo, Reaper, Army Painter)
  • 14 Minitaire bottles
  • 14 Tamiya bottles

Dropper style bottles can be stored in the upright or inverted position. The Reaper paints in the upright position have a little play in them but will still be held without falling over or getting trapped. I designed it more for the inverted position as that is the way I hold my paints to prevent tip dry out.

Follow included instructions for assembly. You will need to print the following to assemble one unit:

One of the following:

  • LeftSide
  • RightSide
  • BottomFront-Small
  • BottomRear-Small
  • Shelf2-Small-(bottle style)
  • Shelf4-Small-(bottle style)

Two of the following:

  • Shelf1and3-Small-(bottle style)
  • RearSupport-Small

Optional - Two of the following:

  • Riser1
  • Riser2

If you use the Tamiya shelves or want to store your dropper bottles upright these risers will attach to the rear of the shelves to raise the bottle height.

Luckily these pieces would fight on the print bed but if it doesn't on yours you may have to split them and glue the two halves together. Assemble with the tabs and slots. I would also suggest glue just to be safe in case you have to move it even though the fit should be pretty tight. Further details are in the assembly instructions.

Hope you enjoy this and it gives you more options to tidy up your painting desk.

Other units in the series:
Large Straight - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2531450
Inside Corner - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2543779
Outside Corner - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2588073
Tool Holder - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2601038

Upcoming:

  • Additional shelves for more paint brands

Revision History:

  • 10/06/2017 - Added shelves for Tamiya brand paints. Also added two riser blocks to so the unit can remain at the same height for any brand paint.
  • 10/09/2017 - Added shelves for Minitaire brand paints.

Happy Printing!!!

title: Halloween Jack-O-Lantern (with a hat!)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
With Halloween stuff starting to pop up, I figured a few people would enjoy a good ol' Jack-O-Lantern. With a witch hat nonetheless! That's TWO (not one, TWO!) Halloween cliches in one! What isn't there to like?

Printing Info:
I haven't quite found the perfect settings yet, but with the overhang of the hat mine turned out a bit stringy at first, but nothing that sandpaper can't solve. Same with the bottom, if you're printing with supports and build-plate adhesion (highly recommended, of course) the bottom won't turn out 100%, just sandpaper/debur it a bit and you should be fine. This may just have something to do with my settings though (or my cheap printer), so let me know how yours turns out!

description.text: I needed another mount for my webcam to fixit ontop of my Ultimaker 2, so i created this...

I designed a couple vases the other day. I've only printed one, the Large Vase (due to large filament cost). The others I'm pretty sure will work... just make sure to have a thick shell.

Not all these are watertight. NW signifies that it is not watertight, while W signifies that it is.

I printed this on a large printer. I would recommend something with about 300x300x400 mm build size... that's what my CR10 has. If you don't have that size, you can probably cut the file into a bunch of smaller pieces (I would use Maya, but I think most 3D modeling programs will be able to do this relatively straightforwardly).

If you have any questions, comments, concerns, or requests for another design, please comment. Happy printing!

author: bugeo_3D

description.text:
This two-piece template was supposed to guide you in cutting and folding a piece of cartstock to make a model with concentric rings that spin when you fold it, like the one shown in the video:
http://youtu.be/2QXgaSLgxq4 Alas! The paper model didn't work very well when I tried it, but I decided to share it anyway. Maybe someone else can get it to work.

The STP files are included so you can try to improve the model to make it work better.

  • Print Twirligig_lower_plate.stl and Twirligig_upper_plate.stl

  • Use the Twirligig_upper_plate model as a guide to cut a piece of heavy paper or light cardstock into a rectangle.

  • Sandwich the paper between Twirlig_lower_plate Twirligig_upper_plate.

  • Insert a sharp knife into the slots and use them as a guide to cut the rings in the paper.

  • Emboss the fold-lines into the paper by pressing down on the upper plate, or squeeze the paper tightly between the two plates.

  • Remove the paper from the frame and use the embossed lines as a guide to fold the sheet. It might not work the first time, but if you work carefully from the outermost ring to the inner one you should be able to get them to twirl as the paper is folded just like the plastic card in the video.
    • More background and pictures on my blog:
    http://mysd300.blogspot.com/2012/06/folding-spinning-plastic-card.html

description.text:
A 1:100 concept model for a holiday house in Western Australia, the site has a very steep slope which proved tricky to model and print succesfully. The project was modelled in archicad, where it was broken into small enough parts to fit the build plate. This also allows for the client to take apart the model and get a better idea of the spaces. The parts were then cleaned with Netfabb and printed on the Makerbot Replicator 2. Fewer issues were experienced with this model compared to the last couple but as always there were a few curling issues and the odd 'ghost in the machine.' Design by Rodrigues Bodycoat Architects:

description.text:
I fitted a download version of the filament fan cover - opening access hingi...the retaining clip ( on my printed one) was a bit iffy. During a print it flopped open and first I knew was the grinding sound when it wacked the left side Z bars. I tried a remix and extended that arm...not really good. I know most may not have any problems with the original versions...but I did and this works for me. Ironically, the clip on this print in the pix..seems to hold position fairly well...but I prefer a "Lock" on the gate.
Also added a support to the front filament fan. I had trouble with the hinges.. mine did not print good. maybe its just the newbie issues - but the support now gives a thicker base to the hinges and not prevent the "gate" being fully opened. I am looking at a moveable hook to hold the gate closed rather than an elastic band.

Also - I added a "support" bar to the second part of this item. I found the hinges tended to break off too easily - it does dot impede the "gate" being opened fully for access to the filament hole.

description.text:
This is just a simple guide for a dry 1.75mm filament box. Recently I decided to make a dry box because my filament absorbed moisture and almost ruined the whole roll. I had searched and searched for a guide but couldn't find one like this that doesn't use Teflon tube. The filament slides through very nicely but should keep moisture from entering the box. I used Simplify3D to print this and if you import model flip it by -90 on Y axis then hit Center and Arrange, you can then import the support structure file and then just print. Hope someone else will find the useful.

The guide need 2X - M3 Bolts
2X - M3 Nuts

Drill a 15mm hole in dry box, feed the guide through from inside and then mark and drill screw holes. Fasten guide with a small cardboard gasket and your done.
Thanks.

description.text: Airsoft L96 Mag Sleeve

A peristaltic pump that uses two cheap 28BYJ-48 stepper motors.  
It's designed for 6mm ODx4mm ID silicone tubing, and is able to pump ~700ml/hr, when the steppers is driven full step unipolar. Higher flow rates might be possible if driven bipolar.

The pump is not the fastest one around, so don't print one if your basement is flooded and you need a pump to get rid of the water. But for watering your flowers, or dosing whatever that needs to be dosed at fairly small amounts over longer periods it should be fine. I have added top and bottom for tubing with 3mm OD and 1mm ID, it is not tested, and will most likely be painfully slow. The steppers can be driven from a single controller, just wire one of them to run the opposite direction as the other. I choose 2 steppers for more torque, this still being a way cheaper and simpler solution, than using a NEMA stepper with some gear reduction. You should probably avoid printing the pump in PLA, if you plan to use it for extended times, the motors run at up to 45-50 degrees C, which might give you problems with softening of the PLA. For smooth operation sand the inner surfaces of the pump housing where the hose is supported, and the bottom part where the bearings is supported. Vitamins needed:
6x bearings 13x4x5 (ODBoreW)
6x M4 washers
7x M4 nuts
3x M4x20
4x M4x5
4x M4x25
6x4mm Silicone tubing, PVC tube isn't really flexible enough. The holes for the motor screws should tapped. I am working on a programmable controller for the thing, based on a PIC12, but don't expect anything production ready anytime soon.
Instead look around on the Internetz, there is lots of examples on how to drive these steppers. Video of the thing running: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uL_5rMrd6TU Code and schematics:
https://github.com/DerSchultze/Peristaltic-Controller It's controlled/programmed via RS232m sequence programming isn't yet implemented, so don't mind the comments in the code about programming lines.. ;) But speed and start up mode cam be stored in the EEPROM.

Did you tested other tubings for the pump!? I'm having some trouble with the motor rotation using tubes of different materials. The motor seems that not have enough torque.

comments.author: Ralf

comments.text:
I tested again with a latex tubing. I was very hopeful but didn't work either. This is probally because of a imprecision printing the parts, so I will try to reprint the tube support part, If it didn't work I'll redesign the space for the tubbing. Other possibility of failling is the code for controlling the motor. I didn't used any library - just called each step directly on a loop - and I don't know if it will cause any loss of torque.
This is the code I've used: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1n1xdo1rpNW6ig6CuNu6DHuPHjgRvLNd6ub-lZnUwyT4/edit?usp=sharing

It's long time ago I made the code, but I have had a look at it again, and I seem to recall that I had some issues with torque.
Try skipping the case statements with only one pin high, that was as far as I can remember what fixed it for me, and made a drastic increase in torque.

comments.text:
Do you really need 6 bearings ? I mean as it is 5mm wide and the ID tube is 4, maybe 3 could fit ? Bearings are 624Z right ?
Thanks !
comments.author: theccm

comments.text: Yep 624Z bearings. You need 6 bearings, because the tube widens when it is pressed flat, in theory it will be half the circumference of the ID which is ~6.3mm wide, a bit less in the real world, due to deformation of the tube. You could maybe make it work with only 3 bearings, but it would probably sacrifice stability.

remixed_from.author: dvhecke
remixed_from.title: Fixed bed level mounts for OLP

description.text:
23-Sep-2017 Update:
Part has been modified as it proved to be about 1.2 mm too tall when installed on my OLP. New v7 part firmly holds the bed at a height of 17.5 mm. Screw hole also enlarged 0.2 mm to better align with holes drilled in the printer based on dvhecke's original design.

22-Sep-2017:
This is a modified version of the bed level mounts created by dvhecke. While I liked dvhecke's mounts I did not care for messing with lock nuts on the underside of the printer.

These revised mounts are recessed on the top surface to accept a nut. This allows the screw to be screwed in from the bottom, independent of maintaining pressure on the print bed.. The three washers are also fully recessed into the mount and held in place with a lock washer and brass knurle nut.

STL file provided is actual size of finished model. If printing on an OverLord printer be sure to scale X, Y, Z. See image for the scaling values on my filament calibrated printer. Pictures are of models printed with 1.75 mm Maker-Bot PLA. When slicing in Cura orientate the part such that the recessed nut holes are facing up. One bottom edge is recessed to account for the lip on the OverLord printer. I printed with supports.

Printer:

OverLord Pro

An extension for the Nerf Deathtrooper Blaster to make it slightly more accurate.

Versions

description.text:
Upgrade part for the Flite Test Simple Cub RC airplane
When built to the plans the back of the wing that sits on the fuselage does not have a lot of support. The force that the rubber bands exert on the wing can fold the back part of the wing and mess up the wing angle. Two of these supports attached to the wing in that problem area will correct the problem.

I printed two supports with PLA, roughed up the surfaces to glue with sandpaper, and then hot glued the supports in place.

The position of the supports is a few millimeters in from the edge of the fuselage with the wing mounted to leave a bit of space for some rubber band protectors (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2549633)

I also smear a thin layer of hot glue over the area of the wing that contacts the fuselage to better hold it in place so it doesn't slide around. This includes the surface of the supports.

description.text:
|Why I make it?|
I come up with this project because i usually forgot my key back home, but the main reason i make this is for fun ;).

|Part List|
-Servo 996R
-Arduino Nano
-Press Button
-Adafruit Electret Microphone Amplifier with Adjustable Gain

|How it work?|
The input of this device is a pattern of knocks(from outside) or hold button(from inside).
If the pattern match with the key, or button is holding, the device will open the lock for 5s.
|F3D (FUSION 360)|
I provide the draw file so you could change the dimension to fit your lock, and the motor you use.
|Wiring Diagram|
Servo(Signal) -> Digital 4
Servo(Pwd) -> 5 Volt
Button -> Digital 3
Button(Pwd) -> 5 Volt
***PS: for the Button wiring you should follow the in instruction from your seller. Button might require a resistor .
Electret Microphone(Signal) -> Analog 0
Electret Microphone(Pwd) -> 3.3 Volt
External (Positive) -> Vin
and ALL Ground -> Ground

description.text:
I needed a screwdriver for cramped areas where a typical screwdriver won't fit (i.e. sewing machine plates) so I designed an offset 90 degree angle screwdriver handle for standard 1/4" hex bits.

There's a small dimple on the end for you to apply pressure onto the screw and a 6" arm to apply a decent amount of leverage. I added a little loop for easy hanging and cut down on overall material.

It is toleranced so that the hex bits fit snug and won't fall out accidentally and the whole thing prints in about half an hour. Enjoy!

Using the following options:

A simple but handy tool in most sewing projects. Useful when needing to pull long strips of elastic into tight places. The horizontal mouths with slight jagged teeth should ensure a secure connection when pulling your elastic through. Simply feed elastic through the mouths and you're good to go. Can also be used with ribbons or drawstrings of various sizes.

Comes in sizes:
large: mouth width of 18 mm
medium: mouth width of 11 mm
and small: mouth width of 5.5 mm

The small holes in front of the horizontal mouths are meant to act as a measuring ruler, with the closest hole to the mouths to represent 0 and each hole after represents an increment of 0.5 inch.
You will also notice that the small elastic threader has a hole behind the mouths which can be used for smaller elastics of other materials or strings if necessary.

If you need and elastic threader of a bigger or more specific size of mouth, leave a comment and I may respond back.

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u2araLZSO0U

This is yet another air powered top. You spin it up with your hand (counter clockwise) and then blow air down the top to spin it faster.

I usually blow through a straw or use a hair dryer on the no heat setting. Once you spin it up, it will spin for about 2 minutes.

This prints upside down on a raft with the point in the air. You need to print this without support or the support material will plug up the air inlet. You need to print with infill because the air ducts through the interior need that support.

print_settings.Notes:: most useful if you print at least three: I'd recommend having 6 or so on hand.

description.text:
I modded Simplemaan's (https://www.thingiverse.com/simplemaan/about) painting support triangle to have a teardrop-shaped opening on the sides. This allows the model to print OK with no support, and perfectly with Cura's "touching buildplate" support.

Prints in about 42 minutes on my Monoprice MP Delta Mini using 0.2mm layer height and 150mm/sec move and print speeds. I included a photo of the original and the modded version for comparison.

The Google Sketchup file with my mods to the original STL are included in case you would like to make other changes (and know Sketchup :) ).

Printer:

Monoprice MP Delta Mini

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2 is fine

Infill:

doesn't matter

Notes:

Use Cura's "touching buildplate" support option to get a clean slot under the 3rd side. This allows the triangles to nestle up closer to each other (but isn't really a big issue - try printing one with no support).

most useful if you print at least three: I'd recommend having 6 or so on hand.

I pulled the original STL into Google Sketchup (it's what I know) and spent some time cleaning out the extra lines from the STL format's handling of a flat surface with curved edges.

I then drew in some guidelines by finding the midpoint of the sides to use as the height to begin the taper. Extruded away the circumscribed area on each side and that's it.

title: Mini Balancing Robot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my version of a small self-balancing robot. A have tried to keep the design as simple and cheap as possible, without compromising performance. The robot uses two NEMA14 stepper motors and the electronics consists of a single Arduino Pro Micro and a MPU-6050 gyro/accelerometer breakout board. Two A4988 stepper drivers (now replaced by TMC2100) are used to drive the motors. The mechanical construction of the entire robot is made up of several 3D printed parts that are screwed together with M3 screws, this makes it fast and easy to assemble.

Only 3D printed parts are available here on Thingiverse. Some parts need to be rotated before printing. This can easily be done in any slice software.

Arduino code and schematics are available on my website: http://axelsdiy.brinkeby.se/?page_id=1447

Update 2017-12-30
Added a new mounting bracket for two Sharp IR sensors.

Update 2018-01-01
Obstacle avoidance code is now available on my website. The robot goes slowly forward and tries to steer away from obstacles using its two IR rangefinder sensors.

Video1: https://youtu.be/nT1FqvNbThU
Video2: https://youtu.be/egfLymeuGhg
Video3: https://youtu.be/dw_tNiF5xEw
